unit: Unit 4 | Probability, Random Variables, and Probability Distributions
title: Binomial Distribution: Brickosaurus' Free Throws
question_text:
Brickosaurus is a $23$% free throw shooter.
What is the probability he makes exactly $4$ out of $10$ free throws? Assume his free throw shots are independent of one another.
solution:
This question deals with being able to recognize a binomial distribution and being able to substitute the appropriate values into the formula.

The requirements for a binomial distribution are met:

The formula for a binomial distribution is:

$$\begin{pmatrix} n \\ k \end{pmatrix}(p)^{k}(1-p)^{n-k}$$

...where $k$ stands for the number of successes which in this case is four, $p$ is the probability of success, and $n$ is the number of trials. (This formula is given on the AP Exam.)

Therefore, our answer is Choice 'A'.

A common wrong answer would be to select Choice 'C'. However, it does not take into account all the possible combinations of making $4$ out of $10$ free throws.

Explanation of Distractors Choice 'B' is incorrect as this represents the probability he makes exactly six free throws. Choice 'C' is incorrect as this does not take into account all the possibilities he makes four free throws. Choice 'D' is as this represents one combination of making exactly six free throws. Choice 'E' is incorrect as this does not take into account all the possibilities he makes four free throws, and it should be multiplication among the probabilities instead of division.
